titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: Robertson and his mother accompanied me to the cathedral where I preached to a great congregation, in which (so far as I could judge) men greatly predominated. The attention was close and sustained. Guy Rogers, Rector of Birmingham, and his wife came to lunch. He is filled with all the windy platitudes of Socialism, but is said to be succeeding in his present post. The University Service was held in the Great Hall of the University, and was attended by a great crowd of students. The acoustics are not good, but I think I made myself heard, though the exertion was considerable. I preached for the 3rd time in S. John's Sparkhill. This is a large church, not very good in its acoustics, and it was densely crowded. Arrowsmith, the parson, motored me to Bishopcroft, where I had supper with Barnes and his wife. It seemed to be a fairly commodious house, and is surrounded by some 16 acres of ground. I talked with the Bishop about the ecclesiastical situation in Birmingham. He is rather obstinate and embittered but seems to have been rather badly treated by these? Catholic Fanatics.
